awd_titl_txt: Minimally Disruptive Optical Interrogation of Intracellular Signaling
awd_abstract_narration:
This program will develop a minimally disruptive approach for using light to control enzymes in living cells. They will pick enzymes of importance in diabetes, obesity, and cancer to address current gaps in knowledge. They will develop a summer biotechnology training program for high school students underrepresented in STEM,  They will assist with the establishment of a core facility for teaching and research in biophotonics, generate publicly accessible educational resources in biochemical engineering and synthetic biology, and create research opportunities for high school students and undergraduates.

They will develop (i) protein architectures (i.e., designs for protein-protein chimeras) that enable optical control of phosphorylation-regulating enzymes (i.e., protein tyrosine phosphatases and protein tyrosine kinases) without interfering with their native patterns of localization and interaction, and (ii) a set photo-switchable enzymes modulated by blue, red, and infrared light. They will supply a specific set of tools for studying the role of signaling networks associated with diabetes, obesity, and cancer, and develop a general approach for analyzing the contribution of spatially distinct phosphorylation events to cellular function and dysfunction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Protein tyrosine phosphatases (PTPs) regulate an enormous range of physiological processes (e.g., metabolism, energy expenditure, immunity, and memory) and often contribute to diseases that occur when those processes go awry (e.g., diabetes, autoimmune diseases, and neurological disorders). This project combined sophisticated biophysical studies, synthetic biology, and fluorescence microscopy to study PTPs in their native biophysical context. It elucidated the biophysical basis of allosteric control in these enzymes and, in so doing, shed new light on their sensitivity to structural pertrubations that occur outside of the active site. It also provided new tools for controling and monitoring PTPs in living cells. These two sets of contributions—fundamental biophysical insights and biochemical tools—will help resolve the contributions of PTPs to important physiological processes (and links between them) and enable new fundamental studies of signal integration and processing in mammalian cells. Broadly, this project has developed research-enabling tools for fundamental and applied research on a wide range of diseases. It has nucleated a set of partnerships focused on (i) microscopy-based investigations of spatial regulation and (ii) structural studies of the biochemical tools that enable those investigations. It has supported a summer biotechnology training program for high school students currently underrepresented in STEM, provided datasets that suport the maintenance and expansion of core facilities that enable research in biophotonics, generated publicly accessible scientific literature and educational resources (e.g., a review) on optogenetics and synthetic biology, and created research opportunities for high school students and undergraduates.



Last Modified: 01/30/2022
Modified by: Jerome M Fox
